texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Anyone who has used a 3G ExpressCard or USB stick knows how handy they can be when you need internet access away from home (and away from Wi-Fi). I've run into some situations recently where I needed to share my 3G connection with more than one device without using internet sharing on my MacBook Pro.
texts.text: Anyone who has used a 3G ExpressCard or USB stick knows how handy they can be when you need internet access away from home (and away from Wi-Fi). I've run into some situations recently where I needed to share my 3G connection with more than one device without using internet sharing on my MacBook Pro.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That led me to pick up a CradlePoint PHS-300 (discontinued by the manufacturer, but available from  Amazon  for about $35). It's compatible with my AT&T USBConnect Mercury (a.k.a. Sierra Wireless Compass 885/885U) USB stick.
texts.text: That led me to pick up a CradlePoint PHS-300 (discontinued by the manufacturer, but available from  Amazon  for about $35). It's compatible with my AT&T USBConnect Mercury (a.k.a. Sierra Wireless Compass 885/885U) USB stick.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Configuring the PHS-300 was extremely easy since I could just associate with the wireless network and enter the password printed on the bottom of the unit. However, getting the 3G stick to work was an immense pain. If you're trying to pair up these products, these steps should help:
texts.text: Configuring the PHS-300 was extremely easy since I could just associate with the wireless network and enter the password printed on the bottom of the unit. However, getting the 3G stick to work was an immense pain. If you're trying to pair up these products, these steps should help:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once the PHS-300 reboots, the USB stick may light up, then turn off, and the display on the PHS-300 might show a red light for the 3G card. Wait about 10-15 seconds for the light to turn green. The lights on the 3G stick should be glowing and blinking as well.
texts.text: Once the PHS-300 reboots, the USB stick may light up, then turn off, and the display on the PHS-300 might show a red light for the 3G card. Wait about 10-15 seconds for the light to turn green. The lights on the 3G stick should be glowing and blinking as well.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: So how did I figure this out?
texts.text: So how did I figure this out?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After scouring Google search results, Sierra Wireless FAQ's, CradlePoint's support pages, and trolling through minicom (yes, minicom), I thought I'd try connecting with my MacBook Pro using the 3G Watcher application provided by Sierra Wireless. texts.text: After scouring Google search results, Sierra Wireless FAQ's, CradlePoint's support pages, and trolling through minicom (yes, minicom), I thought I'd try connecting with my MacBook Pro using the 3G Watcher application provided by Sierra Wireless. Before connecting, I opened up Console.app and watched the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: file. Sure enough, two lines popped up that were quite relevant to my interests:
texts.text: file. Sure enough, two lines popped up that were quite relevant to my interests:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
Fri Dec 16 00:37:51 2011 : Initializing phone: ATE0V1&F&D2&C1S0=0
Fri Dec 16 00:37:51 2011 : Dialing: ATDT*99***1#
texts.text:
Fri Dec 16 00:37:51 2011 : Initializing phone: ATE0V1&F&D2&C1S0=0
Fri Dec 16 00:37:51 2011 : Dialing: ATDT*99***1#

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I didn't have the exact initialization string in the PHS-300 and that was the cause of the failure the entire time.
texts.text: I didn't have the exact initialization string in the PHS-300 and that was the cause of the failure the entire time.
